Copy No._.C A B I N E T 26 (50) .CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the Cabinet held at 10,Downing Street, S.W.1.., on THURSDAY, 3th May,19j)0, at 10,0 a.m. 1, After hearing from the Secretary of Statefor Foreign Affairs a statement on behalf of theBritish Delegation upon the stage of the Anglo-Egyptian negotiations reached at 2-30 a.m. onthe same morning (May 6th), including the reading of a further telegram in -which the G-governor-Generalof the Sudan adhered to his previous attitude(Appendix), the Cabinet agreed To approve the action of the british delegates in formulating to theEgyptian Delegation their proposals in regard to the Sudan which were as follows:-1. Article in Treaty to read -"While reserving liberty to con-clude new conventions in futuremodifying the conventions of1899 and settling the Sudanquestion the High ContractingParties agree that withoutprejudice to Egypt's rightsand material interests thestatus of the Sudan shall bethat resulting from the saidconventions. The Governor-General shall as one of theconsequences of the 1899 con-vent ions continue to exerciseon the joint behslf of the HighContracting Parties the powers conferred upon him by the saidconventions".2. Glause in Note to read -"The two Governments are agreedthat there shall be no discrim-ination in the Sudan between british subjects and Egyptiannationals in matters of commerce and immigration or the possessionof property" .3. Further Clause in Note to read -"It has further been agreed that,if the treatj- is worked in thesame -friendly spirit in which ithas been negotiated, His Majesty^Government in.the United kingdom will be prepared to examinesympathetically a proposal forthe return to the Sudan of an egyptian battalion simultaneously with the withdrawal of the british forces from Cairo" . The Cabinet further authorisedits representatives to continuethe negotiations for the comple-tion of the Treaty and the note on condition that the egyptian delegation accept the above-mentioned proposals. The Cabinet had before them the Report ofPOLICY.the Unemployment Policy (1930) Committee (Paper(Previous C.Ptf-134 (30)) which had been appointed on reference:Cabinet 24 February 3, 1950, to consider the Unemployment(30), Con-clusion 7.) situation in the light of the latest figures and in this connection to have regard to aMemorandum by the Chancellor of the Duchy of lancaster (Paper CP.-31 (30)). The Conclusionsof the Cabinet Committee are summed up at the endo"" the Report as follows:-(i) The Economic Advisory Councilrecently set up was carefullydevised in order to co-coordinate the policy of the Government oneconomic matters, includingunemployment., without overlap-ping with the responsibilities of the Ministers and departments directly concerned, and, whileits constitution must necessarily be tested by experience, it wouldappear to be the most appropriateorganisation for this purpose.(ii) However much we may be criticised,we must not be rushed into shovel-ling out public money merely forthe purpose of taking what must inevitably be a comparatively small number of people off theunemployed register to do Yorkwhich is no more remunerative and much more expensive even thanunemployment.(iii) The Government must be preparedto direct itself to the applica-tion of schemes which will notonly fulfil the condition thatthey provide immediate employment,but which also stand the test of reducing the. cost of productionand adding to the economic powerof the country,(iv) Despite the temporary unfortunate results of intensive rationalisation-tion, we must not be afraid to facethese temporary consequences. TheGovernment has never admitted thatits policy must be tested byimmediate results. We have alwayssaid that we have a well-thought-outpolicy which must take time todevelop.(v) Both for political and. financial-reasons, we must d.o all we can to combat the present feeling ofinsecurity in our financial prospects, and we must, therefore,avoid, all schemes involving heavyadditions to Budget charges orgrandiose loan expenditure.The Cabinet also had before them a Memorandumby the First Commissioner of Works (Paper C.P0-I45(30)) putting on record his reasons for dissentingfrom some of the conclusions arrived at by hiscolleagues on the Cabinet Committee.The Cabinet agreed That the Report of the CabinetCommittee and the Memorandum bythe First Commissioner of works should be referred for examination by a Committee of the Ministersassociated with the Lord privy seal on Unemployment,( First Commissioner of Works,Chancellor of the E&uchy of lancaster and the Parliamentary Under-Secretaryof State, Scottish Office), over which the Prime Minister wouldpreside for purposes of this inquiry.
